content.title: Transcutaneous Oxygen Measurement (TcPO2)
content.definition: A non-invasive method to measure oxygen tension at the skin surface, reflecting local tissue oxygenation and perfusion, used to predict wound healing potential and determine appropriate amputation level.

physiologic_basis.mechanism: Heated electrode increases local skin blood flow, allowing O2 diffusion from capillaries to skin surface
physiologic_basis.measurement: Clark-type electrode measures partial pressure of oxygen

advantages_over_abi: Directly measures tissue oxygenation (not just macrovascular pressure)

equipment: Electrode fixation rings and electrolyte solution

electrode_placement.wound_assessment: Place electrode 1-2 cm from wound edge
electrode_placement.avoid: Bony prominences, edematous areas, hairy skin

wound_healing_potential.borderline: 20-30 mmHg - Healing uncertain, revascularization may help
wound_healing_potential.poor: <20 mmHg - Unlikely to heal without revascularization

amputation_level_selection.unlikely: <20 mmHg - May require more proximal level

clti_diagnosis.threshold: <30 mmHg at forefoot supports CLTI diagnosis

oxygen_challenge_test.technique: Measure TcPO2 on room air, then on 100% O2

interpretation.increase_100: Good vascular reserve, may respond to HBO

positional_changes.supine_vs_dependent: TcPO2 increases with leg dependency in mild PAD

clinical_applications.diabetic_foot: Better than ABI in diabetic patients due to calcification

clinical_pearls: TcPO2 >40 mmHg = good healing potential; <20 mmHg = unlikely to heal
Better than ABI for wound healing prediction, especially in diabetics
Oxygen challenge test predicts HBO therapy responders
Use for amputation level selection - 40 mmHg predicts stump healing
Not affected by vessel calcification (unlike ABI)
learning_objectives: Understand physiologic basis of TcPO2 measurement
Interpret TcPO2 values for wound healing prediction
Know applications for amputation level selection
board_review_points: Better than ABI in diabetics (not affected by calcification)
